thread.title: Small businesses losing overdrafts at a rate of £5m per day
thread.title_full: Small businesses losing overdrafts at a rate of £5m per day

author: Rebecca Burn-Callander
title: Small businesses losing overdrafts at a rate of £5m per day
text:
Small businesses losing overdrafts at a rate of £5m per day The banks continue to reduce or remove overdrafts, putting immense strain on working capital Small business overdrafts are disappearing at an alarming rate Photo: PA By Rebecca Burn-Callander , Enterprise Editor 9:51PM GMT 25 Oct 2015 Comments 
Overdrafts for small firms are being withdrawn or reduced by the high street banks at an alarming rate, it has emerged, restricting working capital for hundreds of thousands of British businesses and hampering their growth . 
Around 17pc of the UK’s small-to-medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have reported that their overdrafts have been removed altogether and a total of 30pc have seen reductions imposed over the past two years, according to a survey of 250 business owners. 
Separate data from the Bank of England showed that £5m-worth of SME overdrafts have been cut every day since 2011, as banks seek to reduce the risk on their balance sheets. 
Overdrafts are useful for covering late payments and unexpected bills Photo: Â© Media Bakery / Alamy 
A report from Funding Options, the online business finance supermarket, has said the overdraft cull shows no signs of abating, placing huge pressure on the nation's 5.2m small and midmarket companies. 
“The withdrawal of overdraft facilities is a significant problem for SMEs,” said Funding Options boss Conrad Ford. “A big reduction in the level of working capital available is not just a one-off blow for a small business but presents ongoing problems until replacement funding is found or built up.” 
Businesses that have periods of feast and famine, such a hotels that secure most of their business in the summer months, will often have their overdrafts removed when cash is plentiful, according to Mr Ford, only to find they are no longer available come February when money is tight. 
The Forum of Private Business (FPB), the national business group, has reported a similar decline in overdrafts, with usage dropping from 25pc in 2011 to around 17pc this year, according to its figures. The withdrawal of overdraft facilities is a significant problem for SMEs Conrad Ford, Funding Options 
“Overall access to overdrafts has stabilised over the last year, but still around 25pc feel that access to finance is a barrier,” said the FPB’s Thomas Parry. “This makes other issues such as late payment and the rising cost of doing business far more important as businesses feel that they have less leeway. 
“In helping our members we have found some banks are more likely to offer overdrafts than others and we will wait to see if the recent recommendations from the Competition & Markets Authority (CMA) encourage firms to switch banks to one that is more in tune with their needs.” 
The initial findings of the CMA’s investigation into the nation’s leading banks were published earlier this month. 
The big banks are culling overdrafts 
It revealed that overdrafts were sought by two-thirds of SME respondents; 83pc agreed that overdrafts are the best solution for dealing with late payments , unexpected expenses and cash flow shortages; and yet 62pc were not offered an overdraft by their bank. 
“The problem of reduced overdrafts is unlikely to abate,” said Mr Ford. 
Banks have been systematically decreasing the number of overdrafts on their books since stricter capital controls were imposed in 2009 . 
They are required to keep reserves equal to the entire amount in overdrafts that could be drawn down at any time rather than the actual amount that businesses are overdrawn. 
“FSB research consistently shows that access to finance remains a challenging area for small businesses, with 32pc of those surveyed telling us their applications for credit were turned down,” said John Allan, national chairman of the Federation of Small Businesses. 
“While a bank overdraft is just one of many financing options available to small firms, it’s currently still a traditional and well-known route for raising capital.” 
Jeff Longhurst, chief executive of Asset Based Finance Association, the finance body, said that more businesses are using working capital solutions like invoice finance and asset based lending, evidence that overdrafts were proving harder to come by. 
“There is no doubt that capital requirements and technology are changing the funding landscape for SMEs,” he said. 
Funding Options’ analysis of 160,000 Companies House records showed that UK SMEs, unable to access capital from the banks, are now using £76bn worth of alternative finance. Banks are helping smaller businesses do what they do best – drive economic growth and create jobs British Bankers Association 
It found that alternative lending to SMEs is now equivalent to 46pc of the value of traditional term loans and overdrafts, which have fallen to £163bn, down 5pc from £172bn a year ago, and 17pc from £197bn four years ago. 
“Borrowers should feel confident about applying to their bank for finance,” a spokesman for the British Bankers Association said. “Nearly eight out of 10 businesses that applied for finance in the past 18 months were given the green light. 
"Banks are helping smaller businesses do what they do best – drive economic growth and create jobs.”
